messageBody:
Hi

I was just wondering if there is some way through which I can subclass the
following
class, with some mopre test methods (probably overridingthe setUp() and
tearDown().But with no
static suite method and when I run the child class all the tests in parent
and child may run.

It would have been very easy to do in case there was no restriction for
suite() method to be static.

I would request you all to pass on any ideas over this.

Because I don't want code duplication by duplicating the public static void
suite() method in
each child class. Where the only thing conflicting is the Class object
itself, which in case
of child should be ChildClass.class.

import junit.extensions.TestSetup;
import junit.framework.*;
public class LargestTest extends TestCase{

public LargestTest(String name){
super(name);
}

protected void setUp() throws Exception {
super.setUp();
System.out.println("--->SetUp()");
}

protected void tearDown() throws Exception {
super.tearDown();
System.out.println("--->tearDown()");
}

public void testLargest()
{
System.out.println("testLargest()");

}
public void testSmallest(){
System.out.println("testSmallest()");
}
public void testVariousAsserts(){
System.out.println("testVariousAsserts()");

}

public void testCollectionAdd() {
System.out.println("testCollectionAdd()");
}
public static Test suite(){
TestSuite retTest = new TestSuite();
retTest.addTestSuite(getChildClass());

TestSetup wrapper = new TestSetup(retTest){
protected void setUp(){
oneTimeSetUp();
}
protected void tearDown(){
oneTimeTearDown();
}
};
return wrapper;
}


public static void oneTimeSetUp()
{
System.out.println("------------->oneTimeSetUp()");
}

public static void oneTimeTearDown()
{
System.out.println("-------------->oneTimeTearDown()");
}

}


*OUTPUT*

------------->oneTimeSetUp()

--->SetUp()

testLargest()

--->tearDown()

--->SetUp()

testSmallest()

--->tearDown()

--->SetUp()

testVariousAsserts()

--->tearDown()

--->SetUp()

testCollectionAdd()

--->tearDown()

-------------->oneTimeTearDown()

Thanks & Regards
Bipin Jethwani

On 7/18/06, clgonsal <clgonsal@...> wrote:
>
> I've been using JUnit for a few years now, and one thing that's always
> bothered me is the "setUp" method.
>
> I always do my initialization in my constructor (if I'm not just doing
> it at the field definition) as constructors allow me to initialize
> final fields. The semantics of using a constructor also seem far more
> obvious to me as everyone reading my code knows Java, while not
> everyone is a JUnit guru.
>
> The additional complexity of having the (as far as I can tell)
> redundant setUp method seems counterproductive, so why does setUp exist?
